blocks.text: SECOND DAY: Saturday, March 29, 1952 – Left Newport 8:30 A. M., south across the Great Smokies on the clearest day we have ever encountered in this area, through Nantahala Gorge, to west edge of Great Smoky Mountain Park to see Fontana Dam, to Chattanooga at nightfall, west across Cumberland Mountains as far as Fayetteville, Tenn. 392 miles (932 miles).

SCALE OF MILES
To Franklin ↓
The Great Smoky Mountains National Park, the most visited national park in America, which we cross on the second day.
The road winds around the side of the mountains.

blocks.text: RRRigight - the road through Nantahala Gorge, which is so deep the Indians named it the Land of the Noonday Sun.
A huge sign helps us to locate our position west of the Great Smokies.
Rruggiggetgitt – Lake Saniteetlelah near Robbinsville N. C.
Fontana Dam, largest in the TVA system, is the highest dam east of the Rockies and the fourth largest in the world. The height is 480'! and the lake formed by the dam is 30 miles long.

blocks.text: TENNESSEE STATE LINE WELCOME DEPT. OF HIGHWAYS
We re-enter Tennessee.

THIRD DAY: Sunday, March 30, 1952 - West across southern Tennessee to Memphis at noon (rain begins), cross Mississippi River into Arkansas to Little Rock (where rain ends), to Clarksville, Ark. 466 miles (1398 miles).
Across the swollen Mississippi River at Memphis, largest city in Tennessee.
Gordon and Kitty find themselves in Arkansas for the first time.

Third night near Clarksville,
Ark...heavy storm during night.
The Capitol of Arkansas in Little Rock.

FOURTH DAY: Monday, March 31, 1952 - through Ozarks region to Fort Smith, into Oklahoma, to Tulsa, to Ponca City; night at home of Marie and Wilfrid Johnson; evening meeting with Ponca City Chapter. 290 miles (1688 miles).
Ozark, Ark. looks anything but the city of opportunity".
The Arkansas River at Ozark which we cross and recross a number of times.

blocks.text:
The wide, open spaces of Oklahoma as we head for Ponca City. Hot - 86 degrees in March.
Hot - 8887 - Hottest - 1049325 ddegreesreeses in Marchen in Marckch..
Tulsa, Okla., "Oil Capital of the World", where Toylee Snyder leaves us for West Texas by train.
In Ponca City we are met by Hal Edinburgh, Executive Secretary of American Business Clubs, who drives with us to visit all the chapters on this trip.
Gordon is presented with a model of the Pioneer Woman statue by Ponca City Chapter.
After breakfast in Ponca City: Kitty, DeRoy Skinner, Hal Edinburgh, Marie and Wilfrid Johnson, Dewell Brown.

blocks.text: FIFTH DAY: Tuesday, April 1, 1952 – Ponca City to Cherokee for noon meeting with ABCClub; to Alva for evening meeting with Alva Chapter; night at Hotel Bell in Alva. 102 miles (1790 miles).
Meeting at Ponca City.
The Great Salt PlainS gleam white in the sunlight as we approach Cherokee for a noontime meeting.
The meeting at Alva.

In Cherokee we are met by A. C. Link,
Jr., Sixth District Governor who attends meetings with us in Cherokee and Alva.

blocks.text: SIXTH DAY: Wednesday, April 2, 1952 – Alva to Enid for noon meeting with Enid Chapter; Hotel Youngblood; entertained at Country Club by Lee and Gwen Kisner, Paul and Betty Fossett. 72 miles (1862 miles).

Hal and Kitty at the entrance
to Hotel Youngblood, where we spend the night in Enid.
Enid is one of the great wheat centers of the Southwest. Here is one of many grain elevators located in the city.
On the Kisner porch: Kitty, Lee Kisner, Betty Fossett, Hal Edinburgh, Gwen Kisner and Paul Fossett, a past national president of ABC.

blocks.text: SEVENTH DAY: Thursday, April 3, 1952 – Enid to Tulsa for noon meeting with Tulsa Chapter; to Oklahoma City; night at Hotel Biltmore; dinner party by Milton and Mary Asfahl at Beacon Club. 260 miles (2122 miles).

We return to Tulsa for a noon meeting with the Tulsa Chapter. Tulsa is Oklahoma's second largest city and well deserves the title, "Oil Capital of the World". More than 500 companies related to the oil business are located here.

EIGHTH DAY, NINETH DAY: Friday, April 4 and Saturday, April 5,
1952 – Friday noon meeting with Oklahoma City Chapter; then to
Chickasha via Norman to see University of Oklahoma; Sixth Dist-
rict Convention in Chickasha Friday evening and all day Satur-
day. 70 miles (2192 miles).
The capitol of Oklahoma, built in the form of a cross, with oil derricks on the capitol grounds.

In Oklahoma City oil derricks are common within the city limits. Oil derricks, or oil well drilling rigs as they're called in some places, are a common sight throughout the state of Oklahoma and beyond. They dot the landscape from rural areas to urban settings like Tulsa and Norman. The presence of these structures is often associated with economic activity related to energy production.

blocks.text: TENTH DAY: Sunday, April 6, 1952 - From Chickasha westward across Oklahoma via Anadarka, Cordell and Sayre to Texas line; to Amarillo's Herring Hotel for night. Met and entertained by Mr. and Mrs. Monte Rosenwald, Mr. and Mrs. Omer Reed.
Our baggage piled up outside the Chickasha Hotel on Sunday morning as we prepare for the trip across Oklahoma to Texas.
We miss a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity when we fail to attend the snake roundup at Okeene, but Gordon can not generate any enthusiasm among his travelling companions.

Almost limitiess space characterizes most of Oklahoma. The land is generally flat and the roads extend for miles in a straight line.
The land is characterized by almost limitless space, with mostly flat terrain and long stretches of road extending far into the distance. This landscape contrasts sharply with other regions where the land may be more varied or rugged.
A typical small town in western Oklahoma where we secure lunch at a most modest price.

blocks.text: ELEVENTH DAY: Monday, April 7, 1952 - Noon meeting with Amarillo Chapter; south to Canyon, southwest through Hereford to New Mexico (Mountain Standard Time), to outskirts of Clovis. 105 mi. (2539 mi.)
Deaf Smith County HEREFORD.
Welcome to New Mexico THE LAND OF ENCHANTMENT
Grain elevators mark almost every crossroad in the Pan-handle region.
A channggeee tttttooooo Mountain Sttandardd Timee when we enter New Mexico.
Typwtypicalcall off the regiionioon of west Texas as we approach the New Mexico line.

An attractive motel on the outskirts of Clovis, N. M., where we retire early.
A long string of random letters and numbers:
Although the land of eastern New Mexico appears flat, actually the altitude is greater than 4,000 feet, the result of a gradual rise from the east for several hundred miles.

blocks.text: TWELFTH DAY, Tuesday, April 8, 1952 – Meeting with Clovis Chapter at noon (joined by Russell Glenn, Eighth District Governor); to Portales for evening meeting (joined by Preston Johnson, lst National Vice President). 20 miles (2559 miles).
The breakfast krfast room; Cal Boykin Hotel, Portales The breakkfast krfast room; Cal Room; Cal Boykin Hndotel, Portales

THIRTEENTH DAY: Wednesday, April 9, 1952 – From Portales return to Clovis, reenter Texas for long morning drive to Lubbock for noon meeting; after Lubbock meeting drive via Seminole to Odessa for evening meeting and dance.
You are leaving New Mexico hasta la vista!
Between Portales and Clovis the dust (no rain since September) permeates the atmosphere.
A good-by to New Mexico.

The flat land of West Texas, very dry with some irrigation, as we speed at 70 to 80 miles per hour for Lubbock. During the night the unpredict-able Texas weather has changed from near freezing to 85 degrees.

blocks.text: The Lubbock Boys' Club, sponsored by the Lubbock American Business Club, one of the outstanding contributions to civic betterment by any civic club in the country. Noon meeting held within the building.
At the home of Preston Johnson, Kitty, Merrill Tripp, mayor of Lubbock and president of Lubbock ABC, Mrs. Tripp, Preston, Hal Edinburgh, and Mrs. Johnson.
Between Lubbock and Odessa the dust is so thick it drifts like sand at the seashore, covers the landscape and creates the impression of impending rain, which would be rare indeed.
A stop for gas at Seminole. Russ Glenn (with Hal Edinburgh), Eighth District Governor, passed Gordon at a speed of 110 miles per hour, while Gordon was travelling a mere 85.

blocks.text: FOURTEENTH DAY: Thursday, April 10, 1952 – From Odessa, through Midland to Big Spring for noon meeting; eastward across Texas to Dallas for Eighth District Convention. 355 miles (3184 miles). Party in Dallas on arrival.
Midland, Texas, said to be the richest small city in the United States (oil), has block after block of fabulous new modern homes.
Some of the oil storage tanks in the vicinity of Midland.
An example of West Texas humor is displayed on this signboard as a "welcome" to Stanton.
After the noon meeting with Big Spring Chapter; outside Hotel Settles where the National Convention was held in l949.
The huge Coosden Petroleum plant just east of Big Spring which we pass as we start the long after-noon and evening drive to Dallas.

blocks.text: SEVENTEENTH DAY: Sunday, April 13, 1952 (Easter) — Again joined by Toylee Snyder; from Dallas to Sherman, visit Lake Texoma at Texas-Oklahoma line, northward across Oklahoma through McAlester and Muskogee, across corner of Kansas, into Missouri to Springfield for night; Toylee leaves by train for home. 457 miles (3641 miles).

DENISON DAM AND LAKE TEXOMA
CONSTRUCTED BY THE U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS
LOCATION ON RED RIVER
MILE MARKER 186
GENERAL PURPOSE: FLOOD CONTROL, RECREATION, POWER GENERATION,
WATER SUPPLY FOR SURROUNDING COMMUNITIES AND INDUSTRIES
FIRM WATER LEVEL 390 FEET ABOVE SEA LEVEL.
SPILLWAY
ELEVATION AT BASE OF DAM 425 FEET ABOVE SEA LEVEL.
DAM HEIGHT 167 FEET
RECREATIONAL AREA 8,000 ACRES
POWER GENERATION: 2 POWER HOUSES, 3 MACHINES EACH 90 MW OUTPUT
TOTAL 270 MW OUTPUT
FIRM WATER LEVEL 450 FEET ABOVE SEA LEVEL.

NATHANIEL OKLAHOMA PRYOR
Born in Va. about 1825, N.E.
Grave 2.5 mi. N.E.
Pryor was related to Lewis and Clark Expedition of 1803 Re-entered army in 1813 as
Lt. L. discharged as Captain 1815.
Entered Indian trade at Three Forks,
on the Verdigris, and soon became one
of the most noted figures of Carlyle's
Oklahoma history First to bring fine

blocks.text: As we cut across the extreme southeastern corner of Kansas.

EIGHTEENTH DAY: Monday, April 14, 1952 – Northeast across Missouri visiting Lake of the Ozarks, to Jefferson City, to Hannibal; north into Iowa as far as Burlington for evening meeting with Burlington Chapter. 359 mi. (4000 mi).

The huge Lake of the Ozarks in central Missour i is 129 miles long and has a shoreline of 1,300 miles. Contained by half-mile long, l48' high Bagnell Dam, built in 1929-1931, this is Missouri's biggest hydroelectric plant. The area has become a vast resort and recreation center.
BRIDGEPORT GOV M.C.LURG LAKE McLURG SPEED BOAT RIDES-SURF BOARD-WATER SKIS SAILING TIME REFRESHMENTS MUSIC DANCING CHARTER TRIPS BEER

blocks.text: Jefferson City (named for Thomas Jefferson) has been the capital of Missouri since 1821; located on the steep bluffs of the Mississippi River; is central Missouri's largest city (255,000 population).

The capitol building erected in
1917, more attractive than most state capitols, is Italian Ren-
naissance, of marble, with statue
of Ceres on dome 262' above the
ground.

Mark Twain's Hannibal, Mo., on the banks of the Mississippi River. Above - Mark Twain's home and museum; right - base of "Cardiff" Hill where prototypes of Tom Sawyer and Huck Finn played; Tom and Huck statue of bronze erected in 1926.

NINETEENTH DAY: Tuesday, April 15, 1952 – Across Mississippi River at Burling-ton into Illinois to Decatur for noon meeting with Decatur Chapter; to Danville, Ill. for night at Hotel Wolford. 267 miles (4267 miles).
Across a steadily rising Mississippi River at Burlington. The River is already well over its banks with the worst to come about a week later.
It is good to see the rich, black soil of Illinois. but the landscape is monotonous in its flatness.
Acres and acres of grain storage bins to house the grain the Government has acquired from the farmers at guaranteed prices.

blocks.text: TWENTY FIRST DAY: Thursday, April 17, 1592 – From Danville to Champaign where Gordon leaves his car to be serviced; Gorden and Kitty drive with Hal and Lacy to Edinburgh for Springfield for noon meeting; then return to Champaign for Fifth District Convention; leave Convention 7:00 P.M.; to Danville for dinner; into Indiana as far as Marion for night.
Kitty and Lacy Edinburgh before Hotel Leland where the National Convention will be held.
With Hall Eddinheinburg,rgh. we enter Springfield for a noon meeting with Springfield Chapter.

We make a quick trip to Lincoln's tomb in Oakridge Cemetery. The tomb was erected in 1874, with contributions from all over the country; remodeled in 1901; and in 1930-1931 the interior was reconstructed.
Lincoln's home, the only home he ever owned, corner 8th and Jackson Sts.

blocks.text: Charles Town, W. Va., named in honor of George Washington's youngest brother who owned land where the present city is established. The sign across the main street may portend the results of the election in November. The court house at left was the scene of John Brown's trial before the Civil War.

Winchester, Va. at the head of the Shenandoah Valley is claimed to be the apple capital of the world. The town was early settled by pioneer Germans from Pennsylvania. After Braddock's defeat, Geo. Washington was commissioned by the Virginia Assembly to erect suitable defenses against the French and Indians. His office (1756-1757) is still well preserved. During the Civil War more than 100 engagements took place within a radius of 25 miles of the city:

blocks.text: On the morning of the third day we once again head for the Parkwayway, this time up the winding Buck Creek Gap road. Visibility gets worse as higher we climb.
The dam which forms Lake Tahoma near Marion.
These pictures give some idea of the almost complete lack of visibility at the top of Buck Creek Gap where we join the Parkway.

BLUE RIDGE PARKWAY
MT. MITCHELL

The Loops
THE CAROLINA, CLINCHFIELD & OHIO RAILWAY LOOPS DOWN THE SLOPE OF THE BLUE RIDGE ON ITS WAY FROM COAL FIELDS TO COTTON BELT. FOLLOWING THE ROUTE THAT TIREDLESS TRAVELER, DANIEL BOONE, AND THE HEROIC KINGS MOUNTAIN MEN WHO TURNED THE TIDE OF THE AMERICAN REVOLUTION, 29 MILES OF TRACK AND 18 TUNNELS ARE REQUIRED TO TRAVERSE 12 AIRLINE MILES IN DESCENDING 1350 FEET TO THE PIEDMONT PLAIN BELOW.
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR.
NATIONAL PARK SERVICE

After driving more than sixty miles on the Parkway in the vain hope the atmosphere would clear, we head for Winston-Salem where we have reservations at the Robert E. Lee Hotel. Dinner with the Lindsay Tucker family; a get-together with the Tucker relatives after-wards; and a late tour of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco plant.
The next morning Gordon and Kitty, leaving James and Grandmother Landreth in Winston-Salem, drive to Charlotte for a noon meeting with the Charlotte Chapter, ABC.

blocks.text: After the meeting at Greensboro, Gordon stops at Sedgfield Inn for Kitty who has been entertained there by several of the wives of members of Greensboro Chapter.

The Second District Convention is held in High Point on Saturday, May 24. Gordon and Kitty spend Friday and Saturday nights with the Dave Martins at their spacious home on Edgedale Avenue. Other guests are Lyle and Helen Smith from Huntington, W. Va.
Kitty and Avil Martin, with her three children and a young guest from South Carolina.

blocks.text: On Sunday morning we drive from High Point to Winston-Salem to pick up James and Grandmother Landreth, then head north for home, via Danville, Va., Lynchburg, Culpeper, Leesburg, Frederick, Md., and York, Pa. to Lancaster. Much of this final day's drive in heavy rain.
